ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Badger Midstream Energy, LP owns and operates a natural gas processing facility, the Grey Badger Gas Plant, in Carson County, Texas. The plant is designed to process natural gas and recover liquid product from natural gas by physical separation and cryogenic means. Petroleum condensates are transported onward to another facility for processing.

Badger Midstream Energy, LP has a long-standing commitment to workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Grey Badger Gas Plant is located near Borger, Texas and operates a variety of processes to produce the following petroleum products:

1. Natural Gas Liquid Product
2. Condensate 
3. Residue Gas
4. Helium

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS

The worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a release of flammable substances at Grey Badger Gas Plant is a vapor cloud explosion involving 271,325 pounds (60,000 gallons) of a flammable mixture contained in one of the two pressurized Natural Gas Liquids Storage Tanks (TK801 or TK802). The entire inventory is assumed to release and ignite, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. Using the EPA OCA Guidance Equations, the 1 psi overpressure was reached at 0.52 miles. The WCS could affect a nearby public receptor. A consideration of the 0.52 mile radius has been incorporated into our notification and emergency response planning.

The alternative release scenario (ARS) for th

e flammable substances at Grey Badger Gas Plant is a vapor cloud fire resulting from the release of the flammable mixture from a pipeline rupture on the bottom of the NGL Storage Tank. The pressurized liquid released is expected to vaporize and ignite into a vapor cloud fire. The resulting release 9,358lb/min reaches the lower flammability limit at approximately 0.10 miles. There are no public receptors in this affected distance.

GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

A. Employee Participation

Badger Midstream Energy encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention as follows:

1. Updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information
2. Performing necessary calculations for PSM and RMP
3. Maintaining good engineering practices
4. Participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team

Employees have access to all information pertaining to the accident prevention program.

B. Process Safety Information

Badger Midstream Energy keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These technical documents address the following:

1. Chemical properties and associated hazards
2. Necessary Block Flow Diagrams of the process
3. Maximum intended inventories
4. Upper and Lower limits of process fixed and rotating equipment
5. Equipment design basis and configuration information
6. Identification of all necessary Regulatory equipment design documents
7. Sufficient information to assure good engineering practices

The location of the technical documents referenced above is listed in the Process Safety Information portion of the PSM.

Chemical-specific information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure considerations, is provided in safety data sheet (SDS). For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperatures, level and compos

ition in the operators' procedures manual. The facility maintains the process within these limits by using process controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems.

The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature and electrical ratings. This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as ensuring proposed process and facility changes to safety features in the process are not compromised.

C. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

Badger Midstream Energy has a comprehensive program to identify and control hazards associated with the RMP covered process.

This program systematically exams for potential hazards and puts controls in place to manage hazards. Process Hazard Analysis is conducted using checklists with a team of Badger Midstream Energy employees who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. The team identifies, evaluates and makes recommendations to management of potential hazards identified. The team's findings are forwarded to Badger Midstream Energy Management for resolution. The approved mitigation options in response to the PHA team's findings are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

The facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.

D. Operating Procedures

Badger Midstream Energy maintains written Operating Procedures of the covered process that address primary o

ations before they evacuate. Badger Midstream Energy has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police and Sheriff's Office). This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition, Badger Midstream Energy conducts periodic emergency drills and annual refresher training for plant personnel.

perations mandated by OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering Practice and manufacturers. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate by management. The procedures are maintained current and accurate revising them as necessary by employee's suggestion, compliance audit, PHAs, Good Engineering practice, Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) and implemented through Management of Change.

Covered Process Operating procedures are readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job task and maintain the covered process unit operating within its safe limits.

E. Training

Badger Midstream Energy has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the covered process. New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. A performance review and written test specific to the facility operations is administered and must be successfully completed during this training period. After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are allowed to work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years, or more frequently upon request. All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.

F. Contractors

Badger Midstream Energy uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenanc

e or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near Covered Process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors:

1. Perform their work in a safe manner
2. Have the appropriate knowledge and skills
3. Are aware of the hazards in their workplace
4. Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency
5. Understand and follow site safety rules
6. Inform facility personnel of any hazard that they find during their work

This is accomplished by providing contractors with:

1. A process overview
2. Information about safety and health hazards
3. Emergency response plan requirements
4. Safe work practices before beginning work

In addition, Badger Midstream Energy Management will evaluate the contractor safety program and performance during the selection of a contractor. Facility personnel periodically monitor contractor performance with regard to their safety obligations.

G. Pre-Startup Safety Review

Badger Midstream Energy conducts a PSSR for any new facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to see that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check that construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and services as quality assurance verification that the accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

H. Mechanical Integrity

Badger Midstream Energy has established practices and procedures for the safe operation of fixed, rotating and emergency shutdown equipment. The basic aspects of the program include, but are not limited to, the following:

1. Conducting training
2. Developing written procedures
3. Performing inspections and tests
4. Correcting

identified deficiencies
5. Applying quality assurance measures

In combination, these activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process.

Maintenance personnel receive training on:

1. Overview of the process
2. Safety and Health hazards
3. Applicable maintenance procedures
4. Emergency response plan
5. Applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.

Written procedures provide that work is performed in a consistent manner and serve as a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help verify that equipment function as intended and that equipment is within acceptable limits. If a deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate safety concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the equipment back into service. A management of change team will review the use of equipment and determine what action is necessary.

An integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. Badger Midstream Energy incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps to determine that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

I. Safe Work Practices

Badger Midstream Energy has long-standing safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, EPA, Industrial Standards and Good Engineering Practice in place to help provide employee, public and process safety.

J. Management of Change

Badger Midstream Energy has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all Reported Covered Processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology and procedures by properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to:

1. Determine that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards
2. Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the proposed change

Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, equipment information and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are trained on the changes.

K. Incident Investigation

Badger Midstream Energy promptly investigates all incidents related to a covered process that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective action to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent future occurrences and forwards these results to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years.

L. Compliance Audits

At least every 3 years a Compliance Audit addressing all OSHA, EPA, RMP and Good Engineering Practices are conducted by employees and management of Badger Midstream Energy. This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed. Final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

M. Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The following is a description of existing features applicable to prevention of accidental release of regulated substances in this facility.

Universal Prevention Activities

Badger Midstream Energy accident release prevention and response policies are applied to all RMP-covered processes. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by

equipment failures and human errors.

N. Specialized Safety Features

Site specific detection and control equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the plant to:

1. Contain/control a release
2. Quickly detect a release, and
3. Reduce the consequences of an RMP-regulated substance release

The following type of safety features are used in the covered process:

Release Detection

1. Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms

Release Containment/Control

1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
2. Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process
3. Automated plant shutdown system to shut down all plant utilities and automatically operate all automatic 
   valves to their fail-safe position, diverting all incoming gas to the emergency flare.
4. Curbing or diking to contain liquids releases
5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)
6. Atmospheric relief devices

Release Mitigation

1. Fire suppression and extinguishing system
2. Trained emergency response personnel
3. Personal protective equipment

O. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Grey Badger Gas Plant has had no RMP-regulated substance release during the past five years.

P. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

Badger Midstream Energy Grey Badger Gas Plant is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The plant maintains a written emergency action plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment. The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.
